replies.author: @JesseP.Watson
replies.text:
@ciarakristos111 You know, tis a strange thought, but... I lived in France for a while and found myself coming home to England and seeing a warrior people here, at least in comparison to those I had just left... and something occurred to me there, it is a bit of a stereotype but anger is expressed more readily over there, and yet, very rarely seemingly do they actually go at it. ...A few pints and we're swinging. ...And we have this obsession with politeness, which is quite unusually prominent. 

Point being, I think we're so polite BECAUSE we are aware that there is warrior blood about us and all it takes is a slight nudge and all hell could break loose to see our please and thank you's replaced with battle cries... Now I might be wrong, but that is my sense of people here. A very, very strong, quite irrepressible sense of justice is one particular trait we have, even if not acted on, it's there - that's not the same in France at least where they'll accept a bad apple and excuse him, likewise bad behaviour often, we don't do that here, we're pretty sure about right and wrong, when push comes to shove. I think that is the warrior code, broiling away in there, engrained deep in our culture. ...So, aye, I think that's why we're so polite, because only a few generations ago, we were warriors and so best not get old Bill riled up, we don't want to have him unleash the old berserker!

Remember, those who journeyed to the British Isles, the far lands of Europe, were the most adventurous, the most foolhardy of those roaming the continent... So, yes, it may be latent, but its in us, we're a breed of adventurers, just need reminding of that fact.

Here endeth the motivational speech. üòâ
